issues.title: set the message key
issues.body:
When the message key is not set, Kafka producer sends the message to the same partition for [10mn](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/0.8.2/core/src/main/scala/kafka/producer/async/DefaultEventHandler.scala#L65) (configurable with `topic.metadata.refresh.interval.ms`). This might lead to data imbalance between partitions when the ratio number of producers over partitions is low.

In this PR, in order to better distribute the messages over the topic partitions, without limiting the batching efficiency, the same key is used every 1000 messages.

The key is randomly generated every 1000 messages.

@liukai @jun-he @nelgau

issues.title: Use interface StatisticsReporter instead of SimpleStatisticsReporter class in UDPListener
issues.body:
@alexism @nelgau

To allow UDPListener to directly send metrics over TaggedMetricRegistry in jitney-proxy dropwizard application, we have to implement a PlogStatisticsReporter class in jitney-proxy project.  Listener class should have a StatisticsReporter instead of SimpleStatisticsReporter. 

This PR contains all the changes to use interface StatisticsReporter instead of SimpleStatisticsReporter class.  Otherwise, we can use plog's python script to collect metrics.

Another alternative way is to implement a jitney-proxy customized UDP listener class, where we might disable all FourLetterCommands.

issues.title: bump Java version, fix links in README.md
issues.body:
- Links in README.md were broken/outdated.
- Java 6 is way out of life now, time to move on.

issues.title: plog.Stress: cannot send only 1 byte payloads
issues.body:
With min_size=1, max_size=1, size_increments=1,

```
Exception in thread "main" java.lang.RuntimeException: No sizes! Decrease plog.stress.size_increments
```

issues.title: Listeners: log which port is listened on
Allow for native transport under Linux
issues.body:
Netty offers a native transport.
It should soon allow for great perf improvements by using `recvmmsg`/`sendmmsg`.
See netty/netty#2719 for early support.

Sadly Plog currently hardcodes the transport to Nio. This should be configurable.

issues.title: Allow multiple `bind()`s
issues.body:
Netty allows us to bind multiple times, which is a very useful performance improvement for UDP sockets under Linux as it allows for multiple listeners.

In that case, it would be useful to allow `threads = 0` and skip the thread pool altogether in `UDPListener`, to avoid the dispatch overhead (including extra context switches).

issues.title: Expose GC stats
issues.body:
It would be useful to expose minimal histograms of GC stats.

See `ManagementFactory.getGarbageCollectorMXBeans()`

issues.title: Expose stats over JMX
issues.body: Could be useful to companies relying on JMX for monitoring, eg via Jolokia.

issues.title: Collect all failure counts into a single object in stats
issues.body: ... so we can sum them into a single metric.

issues.title: Write documentation for filters
issues.body: As soon as that feature is ironed out and used in production, we should document them filters properly.

issues.title: Revamp TCP protocol
issues.body:
Proposal to be reviewed:
- Use `\0` as a line prefix for advanced protocol.
- Advanced protocol supports commands, including stats.
- Advanced protocol allows to specify tags, ask for acknowledgement(?).

commit.message:
Merge pull request #105 from airbnb/update-readme

Update link to example conf
Update link to example conf
Fix test in .travis.yml to actually push tagged builds

Merge pull request #104 from airbnb/rong-setup-travis-bintray

publish artifact to bintray after successful build
publish artifact to bintray after successful build

Merge pull request #103 from airbnb/rong-plog-client

[plog-client] add a PlogClient

[plog-client] add a PlogClient

[plog-client] code review: implement closeable and log better

[plog-client] check constructor args and add unit test for chunk message

fix build issue?

[plog-client] code review and remove openjdk6

Merge pull request #99 from airbnb/luca_luo/add_kafka_encryption_option

[kafka] Add encryption option for message sent through kafka
[kafka] Add encryption option for message sent through kafka

Merge pull request #89 from pcarrier/gradle2

Round of updates

gradle, dependency updates; cleanups

- Inline TERM=dumb in .travis.yml.
- Reindent Gradle config to use 2 spaces, which seems a tad more
  widespread online.
- Download sources for all subprojects.
- Automatically enable annotation processing in the IDEA project.
- Avoid building dist tarball and ZIP in plog-distro (from application
  plugin).
- Use newly introduced 'provided' scope for Lombok. We already skipped
  it in shadow JARs, now it also shouldn't pulled as a transitive
  dependency for projects consuming Plog as a library.

Merge pull request #98 from xinyaohu/make_kafka_handler_propagete

Make kafka handler able to propagate
Make kafka handler able to propagate

Merge pull request #97 from airbnb/alexism/error_handling

error handling improvements

respect the Guava AbstractService contract
notifyFailed or notifyStopped MUST be called, otherwise a terminal state
will not be reached.

Forcibly terminates the JVM if shutdown fails.
Invoking System#exist withing a Shutdown hook migh cause a dead lock.

Merge pull request #88 from airbnb/pierre/defrag/no_synch

Defragmenter: avoid synchronization
Defragmenter: avoid race condition
fix console output for empty tags messages

Defragmenter: isolate multi-fragment code

Encourages HotSpot to JIT the "common case".
Defragmenter: avoid synchronization

Merge pull request #87 from airbnb/pierre/murmur3_stress_tests

Murmur3: add semi-random stress tests
Murmur3: add semi-random stress tests

Merge pull request #85 from airbnb/pierre/plog/fix_encoding_issue

Murmur3: fix support for bytes > 127

Murmur3: fix support for bytes > 127

We only supported bytes with MSB=0.

    groovy:000> -10 as byte
    ===> -10
    groovy:000> -10 as byte & 0xff
    ===> 246

Merge pull request #83 from airbnb/pierre/server/port_hole_debug_logging

PortHoleDetector: easier to debug

PortHoleDetector: easier to debug

Looks like we're getting weird holes at startup.

This should help us investigate.

Merge pull request #82 from airbnb/pierre/single_name_per_pipeline_handler

plog-server: ensure unique names in the pipeline

plog-server: ensure unique names in the pipeline

Otherwise multiple instances of the same handler could have the name
name, which breaks netty.

Merge pull request #79 from airbnb/pierre/style_cleanup_20140512

Style cleanup

pull_requests.title: set the message key
pull_requests.body:
When the message key is not set, Kafka producer sends the message to the same partition for [10mn](https://github.com/apache/kafka/blob/0.8.2/core/src/main/scala/kafka/producer/async/DefaultEventHandler.scala#L65) (configurable with `topic.metadata.refresh.interval.ms`). This might lead to data imbalance between partitions when the ratio number of producers over partitions is low.

In this PR, in order to better distribute the messages over the topic partitions, without limiting the batching efficiency, the same key is used every 1000 messages.

The key is randomly generated every 1000 messages.

@liukai @jun-he @nelgau

pull_requests.title: Use interface StatisticsReporter instead of SimpleStatisticsReporter class in UDPListener
pull_requests.body:
@alexism @nelgau

To allow UDPListener to directly send metrics over TaggedMetricRegistry in jitney-proxy dropwizard application, we have to implement a PlogStatisticsReporter class in jitney-proxy project.  Listener class should have a StatisticsReporter instead of SimpleStatisticsReporter. 

This PR contains all the changes to use interface StatisticsReporter instead of SimpleStatisticsReporter class.  Otherwise, we can use plog's python script to collect metrics.

Another alternative way is to implement a jitney-proxy customized UDP listener class, where we might disable all FourLetterCommands.

issue_comments.body: Looks great! :+1:

This looks great. :+1:

Are you actually using the ByteBufs class anywhere yet?
Yeah, 3 places. Otherwise I would have inlined.

Looks like this was a false alert from our early tests in the `plog` topic.

Snappy very likely doesn't change anyway.
LGTM. Sorry for not catching this on my first half dozen read throughs. ;)

Looks like the port hole detector is finally fixed.

Tested the TCP client with:

```
$ sudo find / > filelist
$ nc localhost 23456 < filelist
```

Sends 1'755'497 messages (only 186MB) in 12 secs on my laptop.

Limiting factor seems to be some locking in the Kafka client.
Incentive for the TCP client: combined with support for unboxed messages in UDP, it makes a mean syslog to kafka forwarder.
I can't really review the TCP stuff, but I'm on board with the rest. :+1:
You might be missing a `builder.append('}');` at the end of `appendKafka`. I see you close the hash for `messageRate` but not for the parent `kafka` hash.
With the exception of my comment on `appendKafka`, this is a :+1:.

He he I was feeling sad about not testing with Kafka in SimpleStatisticsReporterTest.

Let me try to make that work first then :(
Love the testIsValidJSON\* suite! :dancers:
RATIFIED :hammer:
This is a great win. If we do this, we can drop Kafka as a dev VM service. :+1:

This is cool. I'm not sure that we have an immediate need for it but it would make it easy to reuse Plog for other features besides air_events. Round-robin on ports would have the effect of increasing our buffer depth as well. :+1:

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/550416/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/550416)

Coverage remained the same when pulling **26953ef49224bcb5ec4d696437e236e053b90c80 on pierre/fragment_fixes** into **cf0d893e7b9e37c21cdeaa7931b67bee542c8032 on master**.
Looking good. :+1:

[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/551369/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/551369)

Coverage increased (+9.64%) when pulling **2038e0bdd38b8ffa897bc0e747322f067bae778c on pierre/tests/fragmented_message** into **6d56f2f3d9afcb6923d9c5cb78cea88a9d434986 on master**.

:+1:

I kinda did that as an IntelliJ demo.
Not even tested yet.
Thanks!
@nelgau wanna review whilst I start trying to run it? :)
From my reading, this appears to be good. Assuming it behaves an intended when built/executed, this is a :+1:.
I am @nelgau and I approve this message.

commit_comments.body: Actually I'm starting to think that without this, messages with 2+ fragments leak ByteBufs. As we moved to pooled direct allocations, they never get collected.
Interesting. More than just readability... If we hit the `Invalid header` condition, would we have retained the message and never released it?

review_comments.body: Yup, I see now this stat is always upper-triangular.
I recalculated each of these by hand. They're correct. But see my [earlier comment](https://github.com/airbnb/plog/pull/26/files#r10824535).

The `intLog2(expectedFragments - 1)` expression is hurting my brain. As I understand it, the bucket index will be the decrement followed by the position of the highest-order bit... but that scale isn't quite logarithmic in bucket size. With this implementation, we get (I believe):

``` ruby
[1, 2, 3..4, 5..8, 9..16, etc...]   # Note that the first two buckets are the same size. 
```

If the bucket index were given by `intLog2(expectedFragments) - 1` instead, each successive bucket would double in size and (logically; at least to me) begin on a power of two.

``` ruby
[1, 2..3, 4..7, 8..15, etc...]
```

Am I correct? Or way off the mark?
It's not quite logarithmic in size, you are correct. I liked separating 2 and 3-4.
I'm not really swayed either way. We can keep the current behavior.
That was an incredible cleanup. I love it.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,53 +1,78 @@
 plog {
-  // Threads
-  threads = 4
-
-  // 0 or more listeners possible
-  tcp = [{
-    // switch to 0.0.0.0 to be reachable externally, a bad idea.
-    host = 127.0.0.1
-    port = 23456
-    max_line = 1048576
+  defaults {
     // The Kafka topic we will send messages to, STDOUT for no Kafka
     topic = plog
-  }]
 
-  // 0 or more listeners possible
-  udp = [{
-    topic = plog
+    // switch to 0.0.0.0 to be reachable externally, a bad idea.
     host = 127.0.0.1
     port = 23456
-    SO_RCVBUF = 1048576
-    SO_SNDBUF = 1048576
-    RECV_SIZE = 65536
-    defrag {
-      // maximum memory in bytes used to track incoming messages
-      max_size = 1048576
-      // maximum time to wait after the last message is received
-      // to call it quits for that message
-      expire_time = 10s
-
-      // detect holes in message IDs
-      // requires message IDs to be continuously incrementing
-      detect_holes {
-        // counters will still be reported (at 0) if disabled
-        enabled = true
-
-        // how many ports to track before evicting old ones.
-        // cheap enough, really
-        ports = 1024
-
-        // track a reasonably low amount of IDs per port
-        // for fast loss discovery
-        ids_per_port = 10
-
-        // every new message renews a port's lease.
-        // as ports will be recycled, it is useful to avoid crazy stats.
-        expire_time = 1m
-
-        // if a hole between IDs is bigger, it's probably due to a recycled port.
-        maximum_hole = 100
+
+    kafka {
+      metadata.broker.list = "127.0.0.1:9092"
+
+      batch.num.messages = 500
+
+      queue.buffering.max.messages = 1000
+      queue.buffering.max.ms = 1000
+
+      retry.backoff.ms = 1000
+      request.timeout.ms = 30000
+
+      request.required.acks = 1
+
+      compression.codec = snappy
+      producer.type = async
+    }
+
+    filters = []
+  }
+
+  tcp {
+    defaults {
+      max_line = 1048576
+    }
+    listeners = []
+  }
+
+  udp {
+    defaults {
+      SO_RCVBUF = 1048576
+      SO_SNDBUF = 1048576
+      RECV_SIZE = 65536
+
+      threads = 4
+
+      defrag {
+        // maximum memory in bytes used to track incoming messages
+        max_size = 1048576
+
+        // maximum time to wait after the last message is received
+        // to call it quits for that message
+        expire_time = 10s
+
+        // detect holes in message IDs
+        // requires message IDs to be continuously incrementing
+        detect_holes {
+          // counters will still be reported (at 0) if disabled
+          enabled = true
+
+          // how many ports to track before evicting old ones.
+          // cheap enough, really
+          ports = 1024
+
+          // track a reasonably low amount of IDs per port
+          // for fast loss discovery
+          ids_per_port = 10
+
+          // every new message renews a port's lease.
+          // as ports will be recycled, it is useful to avoid crazy stats.
+          expire_time = 1m
+
+          // if a hole between IDs is bigger, it's probably due to a recycled port.
+          maximum_hole = 10
+        }
       }
     }
-  }]
+    listeners = []
review_comments.body: Does this mean that there's no UDP or TCP listener running when you start Plog with the default (pre-baked) config?
Good idea. ;)
And by that I mean — nice "catch."

review_comments.body:
After all, who am I to choose which protocols one should be using? :)

Also, the getting started instructions no longer depend on Kafka.

review_comments.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,10 +1,13 @@
 apply plugin: 'application'
 apply plugin: 'shadow'
 
-mainClassName = 'com.airbnb.plog.App'
+mainClassName = 'com.airbnb.plog.PlogServer'

review_comments.body: Probably doesn't matter but you left an extra space here. ;)
Line alignment by the IDE :dancer:
At first, this one had me confused, but now I see that you're only operating on the first decimal character! (It's getting late)
So I take it that `DefaultByteBufHolder` does not automatically retain the `ByteBuf` passed to its constructor? Does it assume ownership and release it?

There's no ownership, only refcount. Byte buf holders are "releasable", and when released they release their reference to the byte buf itself. Most of our handlers release objects they processed through their class hierarchy when they're "releasable".

-from checks import AgentCheck
+# !/usr/bin/env python
+
 from socket import socket, AF_INET, SOCK_DGRAM, error as socketError

+from numbers import Number
+
+from checks import AgentCheck
+
 
 class PlogCheck(AgentCheck):

-

-			counter('cache.hits',
-				cache['hits'])
-			counter('cache.miss',
-				cache['misses'])
-
-			kafka = stats['kafka']
-			rate('kafka.messages',
-				kafka['messageRate']['rate'][0])
-			rate('kafka.dropped',
-				kafka['droppedMessageRate']['rate'][0])
-			rate('kafka.bytes',
-				kafka['byteRate']['rate'][0])
-			rate('kafka.resends',
-				kafka['resendRate']['rate'][0])
-			rate('kafka.failed_sends',
-				kafka['failedSendRate']['rate'][0])
-			rate('kafka.serialization_errors',
-				kafka['serializationErrorRate']['rate'][0])
-
-		finally:
-			sock.close()
+    def check(self, instance):
+        # read config
+        tags = instance.get('tags', [])
+        host = instance.get('host', '127.0.0.1')
+        port = instance.get('port', 23456)
+        prefix = instance.get('prefix', 'plog.')
+        suffix = instance.get('suffix', '')
+        timeout = instance.get('timeout', 3)
+        max_size = instance.get('max_size', 65536)
+
+        # create socket, ask for stats
+        sock = socket(AF_INET, SOCK_DGRAM)
+        try:
+            sock.sendto("\0\0statfordatadogplease", (host, port))
+
+            # wait for a reply
+            ready = select([sock], [], [], timeout)
+            if not ready[0]:
+                raise socketError('timeout')
+
+            data, addr = sock.recvfrom(max_size)
+            stats = loads(data)
+        finally:
+            sock.close()
+
+
+        def rate(name, val):
+            self.rate(prefix + name + suffix, val, tags=tags)
+
+        def gauge(name, val):
+            self.gauge(prefix + name + suffix, val, tags=tags)
+
+        gauge('uptime',
+              stats['uptime'])
